content.title: Central dogma of molecular biology
content: DNA and RNA are read in the 3' to 5' direction and synthesized in the 5' to 3' direction.

subsections.title: DNA Replication
content: The process of DNA polymerase (DNAP) synthesizing DNA complimentary to a DNA template. The result can either be single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) or double-stranded DNA (dsDNA).

subsections.title: RNA Replication
content: The process of RNA polymerase (RNAP) synthesizing RNA complimentary to an RNA template. The result can either be single-stranded RNA (ssRNA), double-stranded RNA (dsRNA), or messenger RNA (mRNA).

subsections.title: Transcription
content: The process of RNAP synthesizing RNA complimentary to a DNA template. If this RNA will be translated by a ribosome, then it is called mRNA; RNA that is not translated is called non-coding RNA (ncRNA), which is further subcategorized.

subsections.title: Reverse Transcription
content: The process of reverse transcriptase (RT) synthesizing DNA complimentary to an RNA template.

subsections.title: Translation
content: The process at ribosomes (ribosomal RNA (rRNA)) where amino acids, delivered by transfer RNA (tRNA) corresponding to mRNA, are bonded to form peptides. An mRNA consists of a continuous series of triplet nucleotide sequences called codons. Each codon corresponds to a complimentary anticodon of a particular tRNA. Each tRNA has a single amino acid.
